title: Have two bombers ever engaged in a dogfight? Who won? - Quora

response.answer_text: On 17 August 1943, a USAAF B-24 D Liberator fought two German FW-200 Condors over a convoy off the coast of Portugal. The convoy was sailing from Gibraltar to Scotland. The B-24D was from the 480th Anti-Submarine Group to patrol around the convoy to help protect it. The FW-200’s were operating out of an airfield outside of Bordeaux. Neither aircraft were suitable for air combat. The FW-200 was a modified passenger liner and the B-24D used here had its armour stripped to increase its patrol radius and time. German aircraft operating from occupied France had attacked numerous convoys over the previous months. On this day, the B-24D, (known as “The Ark” by her crew) arrived over the convoy at the same time as the FW-200’s. The B-24D, piloted by Hugh Maxwell, dived on the two FW-200’s and closed with the lead Condor. He did not have any experience dogfighting, having flown only bombers like the B-18, B-25 and B-24. His gunners opened fire after the Germans fired first. The lead Condor went down in flames. The second Condor however had landed several hits on the B-24 and set the right wing on fire, knocking out the number 3 and 4 engines. They scored hits on the second Condor and it was last seen flying low to the water with its number 3 engine out. It did make it back to base but crashed on landing and was totaled. Maxwell was able to skid the plane at the last moment before hitting the water that prevented the plane from cartwheeling. Seven of the ten crew survived and were picked up by one of the convoy escorts, HMS Highlander. The same ship also picked up the crew of the lead Condor. It seemed to the ship’s crew that the air crews were on the verge of continuing their fight on the ship but nothing happened. Highlander’s captain stated the dogfight was “really like a sort of Jules Verne scene, with these two enormous aircraft weaving about, shooting at one another.” This was one of many “dogfights” between four and two engine bombers over the Bay of Biscay.

As aerial combat is referred to as either being a ‘fur ball’ or best known as being a ‘dogfight’, which is two or more aircraft maneuvering to gain the advantage on their opponent for the ‘kill’ shot, this is also true when bombers are involved; with the exception of bombers, for the most part, do not maneuver like that of the pursuit/ fighter aircraft. Germany did in fact have four bomber roll aircraft that was used to intercept and destroy Allied bombers in a dogfight, these ‘modified’ German bombers were: Dornier (D0 215) armed with 4 x 7.92 mm MG 17 machine guns and 2 x 20 mm cannons mounted in the nose. Heinkel (He 219) armed with 4 x 20mm MG 151 Cannons in the ventral firing, 2 x 20 MG 151 Cannons in the wing roots, and 2 x 30mm MG 108 cannon aft of the cockpit. Junkers (youn-kers) Ju 388 J armed with 2 x 20 mm MG 151/20 cannons, 2x 30 mm MK 103 or MK 108 cannons mounted under the fuselage, and 2 x 13 mm MG 131 Heavy machine gun remote controlled in tail turret. Messerschmitt Bf 110 standard armament was 2 x 30 mm automatic cannons and 2 x 20 mm automatic cannons in the nose, and 2 7.92 mm machine guns in rear cockpit. As for who won the dogfight between these bombers is like that of two fighters in a dogfight. During a dogfight several factors are placed into motion which is (basically): Advantage: The ‘advantage’ is governed by positioning such as the attacking aircraft is coming from the 6 o’clock (rear), out of the sun (the glare would be blinding the intended target), speed (not only in how fast in a straight line but also how fast one can dive (lose altitude) or climb (gain altitude). Skill: Skill for the pilot (attacking) to gain the optimum firing position or to ‘jinx’ (moving the aircraft from side to side) [the target] trying to deny the attacking aircraft from getting into the optimum firing position. But most of all luck: Some ‘kill’ shots are due to just plain old luck such as, the attacker is unlucky enough to fly right in to a hastily or reckless fired stream of bullets. Or if a fuel tank is hit just right to where the target or attacking aircraft explodes, and then there is the one in a million shot where the pilot or pilots are killed without actually doing any damage that would cause the aircraft to fall from the sky. Again this is just a basic answer to your question.

I shouldn’t answer this because I do not have any specifics and I am depending on my aging memory. Back in WW 2 it did happen from time to time, usually over water. German anti-shipping aircraft VS Allied anti submarine patrols. It must have happened in the Pacific as well. These heavily armed aircraft usually would have 2 or 4 engines and a bomb load of depth charges or conventional bombs. Sometimes they could be float planes or flying boats as well as conventional bombers equipped for long distance patrols. The Focke-Wulf FW 200 was only used as a patrol bomber or as a prewar airliner. As to who won, if an ambush was sucessful then the attacker would probably inflict the most damage. I imagine there were instances of both planes seriously damaging the other and possibly shooting each down. The British had a flying boat that was known as the Flying Porcupine. It was officially the Short Sunderland. It is known to have shot down several German bombers in combat. The US Navy flew Consolidated PBY Catalina amphibians and PB4Y 4 engine versions of the the B-24 as well as many other types.

Nearest incident I can think of Was a dog fight between 8 Ju88 light bombers and a Sunderland flying boat. As far as i can remember this flying porcupine as the Germans nick named the Sunderland managed to shoot down 3 of the JU88’s and damaged several others The Sunderland survived the fight but was quite severly damaged unsuprisingly. I believe it did mange to fly back from the Bay Of Biscay in Western France and reach the UK were it crash landed by the coast.
SU-34 Bomber vs. SU-27 Fighter: Part 2 Yes, the Su-34 remained on tail of Su-27
